answers.answer: Honestly, what got me to lose weight the quickest was having gestational diabetes.  Granted, technically, I didn't lose any weight... but I didn't gain a single pound the entire pregnancy and am now 35-40 pounds lighter than my heaviest and about 25 pounds lighter than when I got pregnant.  I credit the diabetic diet I was on for the weight loss as I couldn't exercise while pregnant due to a hernia.  (and I controlled it with just diet - no meds)You should see if you can find an example gestational diabetes meal plan online and try to follow it.  I never thought I ate very much either - or too many carbs - until I followed it.  But it's not as hard as it may seem, either!First, though, cut out all the fast food.  There are so many more calories in those foods - even more than the processed foods we can buy at the supermarket.  The honey bbq wings have got to go!  Those things are going to have a ton of hidden carbs in them!  And when you do eat carbs, try to get fiber in the same meal to help balance it out (ever gram of fiber takes about 1 gram of carbs of your count).  And switch your drinks to water!!!  It's amazing how many calories we drink every day.Another interesting fact about the carbs - everyone reacts to certain carbs different ways.  White rice is a killer for me, I would eat less than the recommended amount for the diet, and my blood sugar level would soar.  But, I could eat slightly more than the recommended amount of pasta, and my blood sugar level would be fine.  I doubt you'll run out and get a blood glucose monitor to check it, but it's a good thing to keep in mind.  Maybe some of the carbs you do eat are actually affecting you as though you've eaten more than you really did.The only other thing I did to lose my pcos weight is to walk.  I'm walking about 2-3 miles 5 days a week.  Just walking.  I don't know what the trainer has you doing, and I'm not doubting their expertise at all!  Just letting you know how I got the weight off. :)As for the gyno - there are a few options.  If you had your records forwarded to a new doctor, they probably wouldn't need to test or, at least, not so many tests.  If you can't afford a doctor at all, can you try a sliding fee scale clinic or apply for Medicaid?  Good luck - it's worth it!

question: i am 24, and was diagnosed with PCOS when i was 16 or 17. i had and still have no health insurance, and could not keep up with the gyno appts and medication. therefore when i was 19 i stopped taking metformin and going to a gyno all together. i am 287lbs and 5'3. i have been going to a personal trainer 2x a week since april and have only lost 14lbs. i am not following a weight loss plan because i get discouraged when i don't lose weight. i do not over eat, and i do eat relatively healthy. mostly veggies/chicken. i do enjoy white bread and pasta but i have cut that out 99% and now just eat wheat bread(which i do prefer more than white). i eat things high in protein as well. i am not much of a sweets person so rarely do i ever eat candy (in fact i dont know when the last time i did have candy was) and im not much for cookies or cake (unless its for holidays)....foods that i eat on a weekly basis consist of peanutbutter, wheat english muffins, plain popcorn, chick peas, plain oatmeal, vegetables, salads, cheese...i have a weakness for subways honey oat bread w/ shredded cheese and veggies(a veggie sub with cheese)...i also eat quinoa alot.some of the foods that i eat when i go out would be boneless honey bbq wings, if i eat at mcdonalds or burger king i get chicken nuggets...i do love diet soda and i have been trying to eliminate that all together. i have never in my life drank regular soda but my trainer told me that even diet soda is no good. basically i need to know what foods i should be eating on a daily basis, how many calories etc....i know metformin would help me but i can't get to a new gynocologist to run tests all over again and treat me for it since i financially cant afford it. any help would be appreciated. i am tired of looking in the mirror everyday and would do anything just to lose weight
title: PCOS and weightloss
